title: Swimming Vocabulary
description: Dive into the terminology of competitive and recreational swimming!

questions.question: In competitive swimming, what is a 'flip turn'?
options: A diving technique off the starting block
A type of relay exchange
A backstroke start method
A somersault turn at the wall to reverse direction
questions.explanation: A flip turn is a technique where a swimmer performs an underwater somersault near the wall, pushes off with the feet, and continues swimming, used primarily in freestyle and backstroke.

questions.question: What is the 'individual medley' (IM) in swimming?
options: A solo race at any distance
A relay race with four different swimmers
A race where the swimmer chooses their own stroke
A race where one swimmer swims butterfly, backstroke, breaststroke, and freestyle in sequence
questions.explanation: The individual medley (IM) requires a single swimmer to swim equal distances of butterfly, backstroke, breaststroke, and freestyle, in that specific order.

questions.question: In swimming, what is a 'false start'?
options: Swimming the wrong stroke
Starting from the wrong lane
Leaving the starting block before the signal
Touching the wall with one hand in breaststroke
questions.explanation: A false start occurs when a swimmer leaves the starting block or begins their motion before the starter's signal, resulting in disqualification.

questions.question: What does 'DQ' stand for in competitive swimming?
options: Disqualification
Delayed Qualifying
Double Qualifier
Distance Qualified
questions.explanation: DQ stands for disqualification, which occurs when a swimmer violates the rules, such as an illegal stroke, false start, or improper turn.

questions.question: In swimming, what is the 'catch' phase of a stroke?
options: The initial part of the pull where the hand engages the water
Grabbing the lane rope for support
The final touch at the wall
Catching a breath during the stroke
questions.explanation: The catch is the initial phase of the arm pull where the swimmer's hand and forearm engage the water to begin generating propulsion.

questions.question: What is a 'negative split' in swimming?
options: Losing time in each successive lap
Splitting into separate lanes during warm-up
A poor finish in a relay
Swimming the second half of a race faster than the first half
questions.explanation: A negative split means swimming the second half of a race faster than the first half, often considered an ideal pacing strategy.

questions.question: In swimming, what is 'drafting'?
options: Creating waves to slow an opponent
Swimming closely behind another swimmer to reduce resistance
Writing race strategy on paper
Choosing which heat to swim in
questions.explanation: Drafting is swimming in the slipstream created by the swimmer ahead, which reduces water resistance and requires less energy, commonly used in open water swimming.

questions.question: What is a 'taper' in swimming training?
options: A gradual increase in training intensity before a competition
A gradual decrease in training volume before a major competition
A tapering swimsuit design
Narrowing the pool lanes for practice
questions.explanation: A taper is a planned reduction in training volume and intensity before a major competition, allowing the body to recover and perform at its peak.

questions.question: In swimming, what is the 'dolphin kick'?
options: A kick used only in backstroke
An undulating kick where both legs move together like a dolphin's tail
A single powerful kick off the wall
A kick performed above the water surface
questions.explanation: The dolphin kick is a simultaneous up-and-down motion of both legs together, used in butterfly stroke and during underwater phases after starts and turns.

questions.question: What is a 'heat' in competitive swimming?
options: A preliminary round of a race to determine finalists
The intensity of a workout
The water temperature of the pool
A warm-up swim before the main event
questions.explanation: A heat is a preliminary round of racing. When there are more swimmers than lanes, multiple heats are swum, and the fastest times advance to semifinals or finals.

questions.question: In swimming, what does 'streamline' refer to?
options: A body position with arms extended overhead and body tight to minimize drag
Swimming in a straight line
A type of racing swimsuit
A pool with a current
questions.explanation: Streamline is a hydrodynamic body position where the swimmer extends their arms overhead with hands stacked, squeezing ears between biceps, to minimize water resistance.

questions.question: What is a 'touchpad' in competitive swimming?
options: A device swimmers wear on their fingers
A rubber mat at the bottom of the pool
A writing surface for coaches
An electronic plate on the wall that records finish times when touched
questions.explanation: A touchpad is a pressure-sensitive electronic plate mounted on the wall at each end of the pool that precisely records the time when a swimmer touches it.

questions.question: In swimming, what is an 'open turn'?
options: A turn performed in open water
A turn made while breathing
A turn without touching the wall
A turn where the swimmer touches the wall with one or both hands before pushing off
questions.explanation: An open turn is a turn where the swimmer touches the wall, pulls the knees in, rotates, and pushes off. It is required in breaststroke and butterfly where two-hand touches are mandatory.

questions.question: What does 'pulling' mean in swim training?
options: Pulling a teammate through the water
Swimming using only arm strokes with a pull buoy between the legs
A disqualification for grabbing the lane line
Removing lane ropes before a race
questions.explanation: Pulling is a training drill where swimmers use only their arms for propulsion, typically with a pull buoy between the thighs to keep the legs afloat and still.

questions.question: In swimming, what is a 'split time'?
options: The time difference between two swimmers
The intermediate time recorded at specific distances during a race
The time a swimmer spends resting between races
The time it takes to change strokes in a medley
questions.explanation: A split time is the time recorded at intermediate points during a race, such as every 50 or 100 meters, allowing analysis of a swimmer's pacing strategy.
